headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us for Ulta Beauty's first quarter 2016 conference call. Hosting our call are Mary Dillon, Chief Executive Officer; and Scott Settersten, Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us as Dave Kimbell, Chief Merc
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us for Ulta Beauty's first quarter 2016 conference call. Hosting our call are Mary Dillon, Chief Executive Officer; and Scott Settersten, Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us as Dave Kimbell, Chief Merchandising and Marketing Officer. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you the company's safe harbor language. Statements contained in this conference call which are not historical fact may be deemed to constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual future results may differ materially from those projected in such statements due to a number of risks and uncertainties, all of which are described in the company's filings with the SEC. 
[Operator Instructions] I'll now turn it over to Mary.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura. Good afternoon, everyone. 2016 is off to great start with excellent top and bottom line growth in our first quarter. There are several factors coming together to drive momentum in our business: healthy consumer demand in the beauty categ
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura. Good afternoon, everyone. 2016 is off to great start with excellent top and bottom line growth in our first quarter. There are several factors coming together to drive momentum in our business: healthy consumer demand in the beauty category, ULTA Beauty's unique and relevant format and positioning and effective collaboration across the enterprise, which is driving strong execution of our growth strategy. 
To recap the first quarter results: we drew -- grew the top line 23.7% and delivered a 15.2% comp on top of an 11.4% comp in the first quarter 2015. This is our best comp growth since 2006. Comp sales were driven primarily by traffic, while ticket also saw healthy increases. Ongoing strength in cosmetics, both mass and prestige, is largest contributor to our growth, but other major categories for delivering robust comps as well. E-commerce continues to see rapid sales growth. The Salon's top line was selling, even while we reduced the frequency of our promotion period. So with the overall revenue growth significantly better than planned, coupled with strong execution of our strategic imperatives, we delivered earnings per share growth of almost 40%, well above our expectations. 
I'd like to call out some more specific details on the primary contributors for our performance during the quarter. Growth in our loyalty program continues to fuel business results. ULTAmate Rewards membership grew to 19.4 million active members, up 25% year-over-year. This continued acceleration of sign-ups reflect store associates' efforts to convert new members and strong traffic driven apart by our advertising campaign. 
The number of members shopping increased as well as their sales ticket per visit. loyalty member retention increased each quarter and is up almost 200 basis points compared to last year. Using the loyalty program points as currency, our CRM team is working closely with our merchants and our brand partners to continue developing targeted and relevant campaigns that are increasingly resonating with our guests. 
Our marketing mix continues to evolve with great balance across television, radio, digital and social media as well as our traditional print vehicle. In March, we ran television and radio ads for our signature 21 Days of Beauty event. complemented this with an aggressive online video campaign as well as extensions into online radio with Spotify and Pandora. 
We elevated our social media and influence efforts anchored on our spring trends. We surrounded our consumer with current and relevant content online and in-store as well as activation at high-profile events, including the Coachella music Festival. Our comprehensive campaign for Mother's Day, which was called pamper Her with  , was designed to build awareness that our brand, deepen our connection with our guests and provide a platform to make ULTA Beauty a top-of-mind destination for gift-giving, especially in fragrance. In addition to the return of the Mother's Day gift guide and fragrance finder, we offered more gifts purchase and CRM promotions in conjunction with many exciting new fragrance launches. The Mother's Day activities also included a social media campaign with the launch of a special video entitled Mom, the Original Beauty Icon, which invited guests to celebrate mom by sharing what makes their own moms' beauty iconic through a post on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. This campaign was viewed over 4.5 million times. We believe all these marketing efforts contributed to our strong traffic growth during the quarter. 
Now to update you on merchandising. The trends from last year continued to drive business, with Urban Decay, cosmetics, Mix, , Too Faced,, Clinique, Lancôme, Benefit and Ulta Beauty Collection along the best performing brands in the quarter. The pipeline of newness really continues to be quite compelling, translating into strong growth in both mass and prestige cosmetics. During the quarter, we launched Honest [ph] Beauty in 250 stores, rolled out our exclusive Feeling the [indiscernible] in 500 stores and added Cosmetics to all doors. Anastacia, Beverly Hills and launched new product lines. Clarence was rolled out to additional doors. We entered [indiscernible] Double Duty beauty Collection, which is exclusive to ULTA Beauty. And we rolled that Dior mascara to all stores. 
More recently, we announced the addition of [indiscernible] hair care products, and we began to offer a French skincare brand on our website. We also rolled out an assortment of the iconic drive bar hair products and tools in hundreds of stores. 
We are enhancing our ULTA Beauty Collection through a series of initiatives. we've been updating and elevating the formula and packaging as well as the in-store graphics, while improving speed to market and on trend products. Trend categories include contouring, strobing and multidimensional makeup. And we've also added an featuring new spring kids. We've produced compelling training videos and enhanced our sampling program. while we've made great progress, we're just getting started with our efforts to involve ULTA Beauty Collection to continue to represent our brand personality. 
Turning to services. Our salon sales rose 14.7% and comped 7.7%, with strength in blowouts, hair treatment and makeup services. We view the services business as a growth opportunity, and we're very focused on our strategy to convert more of our loyalty members to discover a high-quality services offering. Our Benefit Brow Bar business continued its strong performance, with brow services now in 738 stores. And we're proud to perform more brow service than anyone else in the U.S. 
Moving on to stores. We opened 13 stores and closed one in the first quarter, well on our way to executing our 2016 program of 100 net new stores. We ended the quarter with 886 stores. New store productivity remains very strong, with all vintages of stores benefiting from the successful execution of our strategic imperatives. Our growth and development team is now in the process of performing a deep dive analysis to refresh our estimate of the store potential in the U.S. This analysis includes an updated assessment of the potential for smaller and urban market as well as how our small store format will fit into the future storm mix.  Sharing the outcome of this work is expected to be one of the topics we plan to cover at our next Analyst Day this fall as well as other updates from our long-term strategic plan that we're now in the process of refreshing as well. 
Moving on to www.ulta.com. Our e-commerce growth was very strong, up 38.8% and contributing 130 basis points of total company comp. The mix of professional health care and prestige cosmetics continues to grow, helping our e-commerce margin rate. We are also adding brands and products that are available online such as Beauty,   hair care,   [indiscernible] among others. Our ulta.com guests remain very interested in our beauty bag sampling program and beauty break limited time promotions. 
Mobile is growing rapidly, now representing more than 60% of site traffic. We released new versions of our iPhone and Android apps in the first quarter. The iPhone app was featured on Apple Store home page. Moving up to a 5-star rating, this new version now includes features such as Apple Pay checkout, enhanced features displaying ULTAmate Rewards information and Gifts with Purchase details on product pages. Both app versions have been a big hit with users, garnering enthusiastic user reviews and an increase in downloads, now reaching well over 2 million between the two. 
Finally, our supply chain and IT teams have done a great job managing the ramp-up of the Greenwood distribution center while preparing to open our distribution center in Dallas, which began inbound inventories last week. The Greenwood DC is now serving about 200 stores and fulfilling roughly 40% of our e-commerce orders. We're on track to end the year delivering to approximately 240 stores from Greenwood. 
Our Dallas facility, a carbon copy of our Greenwood building, is right on track to begin outbound shipments in July as planned. We expect to ramp up this newest DC to serve 125 stores by holiday. As expected, the Greenwood distribution center and systems are producing efficiencies and cost per unit shipped. 
On the system side, we have good progress to report here as well. Swift, our forecasting replenishment tool, has been rolled out to additional categories including skincare and health care, and rest of categories will be implemented throughout the remainder of the year. I am particularly proud of the supply chain team and IT teams' performance in the collaboration and balancing execution of several major initiatives and projects while of doing an excellent job improving in stocks in our stores to support the higher-than-expected sales trends. 
So now I'll turn it over to Scott to discuss the drivers of our first quarter results and outlook for the second quarter and the year.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mary. Good afternoon, everyone. Starting with the income statement. Similar to previous quarters, our top line was driven by a very healthy 15.2% comp and strong new store productivity. The total company comp was composed of 11% transaction grow
componenttext:
Thanks, Mary. Good afternoon, everyone. 
Starting with the income statement. Similar to previous quarters, our top line was driven by a very healthy 15.2% comp and strong new store productivity. The total company comp was composed of 11% transaction growth and 4.2% average ticket growth. The retail comp of 14.3% was made up 10.5% traffic and 3.8% ticket. The Salon business comped 7.7%, and salon growth was all ticket based. e-commerce growth was almost entirely driven by traffic, with modest ticket growth. 
Gross profit increased 150 basis points. The improvement was driven by strong leverage on store rent and occupancy expenses as well as product margin expansion, offset by planned supply chain deleverage related to investments in new distribution centers and core merchandising systems. Strong product margin performance was driven in part by significant margin improvement in mass departments due to changes in our promotional offers and a mix of higher margin brands, including the ULTA Beauty Collection. We continued to carefully pull back on broad discounting, while placing more reliance on loyalty and our CRM tool kit. 
Moving on to SG&A expenses. We deleveraged by 20 basis points, primarily related to investments and headcount and consulting to support our growth initiatives. 
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. Inventories were up 14.5% on a per-store basis, slightly below the comp rate. This growth was driven by investments in inventory to keep up with better-than-expected top line growth, new brand additions and the accelerated expansion of prestige boutiques. In-stock levels have improved year-over-year, but we still expect to make more progress going forward as we begin to reap the benefits of our new distribution centers and related systems. 
Capital expenditures were $54.3 million in the quarter driven by new store openings, merchandise features for the rollout of prestige brand boutiques and supply chain and system investments. 
We ended the quarter with $369 million in cash and short-term investments. 
We repurchased 158,000 shares at a cost of $27 million under our 10b5-1 plan. And as you know, we entered into a $200 million ASR agreement in March, which settled just last week. During the first quarter, we received 80% of the shares we expected to receive on settlement, or about 852,000 shares. The reduction in shares outstanding year-over-year contributed approximately $0.03 of earnings per share growth in the quarter. Including the entire $200 million paid as part of the ASR agreement, approximately $219 million remained available under the $425 million share repurchase program announced in March. 
Turning now to guidance for the second quarter. We anticipate sales to be in the range of $1.041 billion to $1.058 billion compared to $877 million last year. We expect comparable sales to increase in the range of 11% to 13% versus 10.1% last year. Online sales growth is expected to be in the 40% range. We plan to open about 25 stores in Q2 compared to 20 stores during the same period last year. And preopening expense for the quarter is expected to be about $4.6 million. 
Earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $1.32 to $1.37 versus $1.15 for Q2 of 2015.  Our supply chain investments, including new Dallas DC, are expected to weigh on margins the most in the second and third quarter. And we expect earnings per share growth to be higher in the fourth quarter this year.  We anticipate a tax rate of 37.6% and a fully diluted share count of approximately 63 million. 
In terms of our outlook for the full year 2016, we are raising our guidance for comparable sales and earnings per share growth to reflect the strong start to the year. Total company comps are now expected to be approximately 10% to 12% compared to our prior guidance of 8% to 10%. We now expect to grow earnings per share in the low 20s percentage range versus our prior guidance of 18% to 20% growth. Operating margins are now expected to leverage slightly. 
The other elements of our guidance for the year are unchanged. We are on track to open approximately 100 stores, all planned to be on 10,000 square foot prototype. We expect to open about 25 stores in Q2, 50 stores in Q3 and 15 stores in Q4. 
We're also planning 12 major remodels and 2 relocations. We plan to grow e-commerce approximately 40%. We expect CapEx to be about $390 million, driven by higher capital per new store and the rollout of boutiques. As a reminder, we planned about $80 million for boutique expansion and updates, with over 500 Clinique, Lancôme and Benefit boutiques as well as updates to our fragrance fixtures and the ULTA Beauty Collection. 
We anticipate that share repurchase activity under our $425 million authorization will contribute about 2 percentage points of earnings per share growth. 
I'll now turn the call over to our conference call host for the Q&A session. Operator?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. Well I guess, first of all what I'd say is what we saw was pretty consistent across the quarter in terms of the comp. It's not a lot of variation. Where we did see variation, it was maybe cadence of promotion than we had planned. So I th
componenttext: Thank you, Chris. Well I guess, first of all what I'd say is what we saw was pretty consistent across the quarter in terms of the comp. It's not a lot of variation. Where we did see variation, it was maybe cadence of promotion than we had planned. So I think at the end of the day, beauty as a category is a great place to be as you know. And its healthy's category and it's fairly, we think, insulated from some of the factors that are affecting may be retail broadly. And in particular, our -- what we bring to the marketplace in terms of this differentiator proposition categories, various price points our products and services, we think makes is pretty insulated right now. And we're pretty proud of the results.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then as a follow-up, can you just talk about the performance, the comp performance in the mature store base and how that impacts your view on potential store penetration over the long term?
componenttext: Understood. And then as a follow-up, can you just talk about the performance, the comp performance in the mature store base and how that impacts your view on potential store penetration over the long term?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can. Our store model reflects mature stores 5 years and older kind of moderate and comp kind of middle, low single-digit kind of comps over the long term. With the 15 comp in total, as you can well imagine, Chris, I mean the existing store base, ve
componenttext: Yes, I can. Our store model reflects mature stores 5 years and older kind of moderate and comp kind of middle, low single-digit kind of comps over the long term. With the 15 comp in total, as you can well imagine, Chris, I mean the existing store base, very healthy comps overall, very productive on the   contribution line, which is a huge contributor to the profit increases that we saw year-over-year. As we look to the future, I mean, that's part of the mix. We're adding the boutiques. That's why we're being so aggressive with the CapEx this year and get those installed. We believe that as well as with all the other great purchase of pipeline that we have coming onboard, loyalty on top of that, some of the marketing and advertising kind of initiatives we have underway, we think all of those things together will come together to drive really strong productivity in our existing store base.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

componenttext: I guess first question on the ULTAmate Rewards program, obviously, hugely successful for you guys. You're now well north of 19 million. First, how high can that number get? I guess you guys I'm sure done demographic analysis in terms of the potential size of that. And secondly, if you can remind us what percentage of your sales comes from your loyalty club members.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Well first of all, I would say we've said it's well over 80%, over 80% of our sales are driven by the loyalty program members. We're really pleased with how that's working for our business. The -- it's really one of the key drivers of the
componenttext: Thank you, Joe. Well first of all, I would say we've said it's well over 80%, over 80% of our sales are driven by the loyalty program members. We're really pleased with how that's working for our business. The -- it's really one of the key drivers of the results that we're seeing is the acceleration in members entering the program. proud about our store teams being able to convert new traffic and new members into the store and into the program. How high is that? I mean, certainly, we have to resolve that question as well. As we think about kind of long-term view of the business, it's going to be obviously a very key driver for us as we move forward. And if you step way back and look at it, our share of the market in beauty in the U.S. is still only 3% or so of the total market, right? So we know there's a lot of growth ahead. And we're very focused on understanding kind of what it is about loyalty program that drives the appeal in continue to make sure that we fine-tune it going forward. So we think there's more growth there certainly, and I think our results are showing that.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood, and then just moving on I guess one for Scott. The guide for Q2, you mentioned was like a earnings per share down sequentially. That's seasonally unusual. You mentioned some of the costs related to Dallas hitting you in 2Q and 3Q. You ha
componenttext: Okay, understood, and then just moving on I guess one for Scott. The guide for Q2, you mentioned was like a earnings per share down sequentially. That's seasonally unusual. You mentioned some of the costs related to Dallas hitting you in 2Q and 3Q. You had Greenwood facility around the same time last year, and yet, you had sequential earnings improvement in 2Q. So I'm just curious, is Dallas bigger in terms of the impact? Or is the timing a little bit moved forward relative to Greenwood?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would say it's probably more along the lines of a couple of new factors this year. So I guess we kind of talked about the DCs and the lapping effect there year-over-year. So not a huge change there, I would say, in the sequence. We do have accelerat
componenttext: No, I would say it's probably more along the lines of a couple of new factors this year. So I guess we kind of talked about the DCs and the lapping effect there year-over-year. So not a huge change there, I would say, in the sequence. We do have accelerated depreciation from this boutique acceleration that we talked about, so again, you guys can't model that very accurately. But that's a little bit lumpy, and it's kind of first half of the year kind of weighted, I would say. And then we also have some store payroll implications related to the same boutique strategy, right? So I think we explained back in the fourth quarter that it takes a lot for those boutiques to ramp up, right? So they're being installed now and we got some payroll investment there in the early days, which over time, moderates and plays very well part from a profitability standpoint. So it's really the payroll piece, and some of it's the depreciation that's related there, That's causing it.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So excited to you guys are having an Analyst Day in the fall. It sounds like the footage on the smaller stores, you'll be updating us on. But I guess I was curious about the mid-teen operating margin that you have been talking about. I guess you look at t
componenttext: So excited to you guys are having an Analyst Day in the fall. It sounds like the footage on the smaller stores, you'll be updating us on. But I guess I was curious about the mid-teen operating margin that you have been talking about. I guess you look at these double-digit comps you've been running, I guess the question is, can you get to a mid-teen operating margin target faster? Or is there anything impairing you from getting to high teens operating margin over the next couple of years? So curious on that. And then from a market share perspective, when we all look at the department store numbers they've been putting up the last couple of quarters, can you maybe talk how that affects the brand conversations? So are there still major holdouts regarding brands that you'd like to be offering your guests, that might be still looking at the department stores as one of their key channels of distribution?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Brian. And your first question, well, I'm not going to  [indiscernible] our guidance today.   nice try though. like I said, really fair question. I'd say this. We're very confident. First of all, we're thrilled with the products of the bu
componenttext: Okay, thank you, Brian. And your first question, well, I'm not going to  [indiscernible] our guidance today.   nice try though. like I said, really fair question. I'd say this. We're very confident. First of all, we're thrilled with the products of the business. I mean, I think that should be pretty clear and confident that we understand the drivers, and we see plenty of growth ahead. We're confident in the mid-teen operating margin target that we've stated previously. I think what you'll see is we -- we're looking to refresh our view, but feel good about where we are. I wouldn't expect to change our outlook materially. We believe we can continue to drive top line and invest in the business for the long-term as well as drive efficiencies with the investments that we're making today. And while we're thrilled about the top line momentum, I think all of us would say consumer expectations in the future will continue to evolve. And so we need to be prepared to be able to respond in some areas, [indiscernible] in some areas. So that makes cautious about getting more aggressive about that margin target.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and Brian, it's Dave in here. On the second question about adding new brands in this environment, I'd start with saying that we're really focused on growing our business with our existing brands, and that's working very well for us. We've got a gre
componenttext: Great, and Brian, it's Dave in here. On the second question about adding new brands in this environment, I'd start with saying that we're really focused on growing our business with our existing brands, and that's working very well for us. We've got a great portfolio of brands across all categories. And that's been very successful and we continue to drive success for us going forward. And into that, Mary mentioned some of the brands that we've added just in the last quarter. You've heard that. We've added well over 100 over the last several years. So we're always looking at new brands. And as our growth continues, I think we're an attractive partner for brands. So we'll continue to be having discussions and exploring opportunities. But right there, really focused on continuing to drive behind the success that we've been having.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

componenttext: I guess I want to go back to talking about maybe the omnichannel customer, and I know you talked about e-com was up almost 40%. A lot of that was traffic driven. So I was just wondering, as you're kind of learning more with loyalty card and CRM and the personalization. How are you getting that transaction size of that omnichannel customer to kind of increase? And any updated outlook in terms of how big that customer could actually become as a part of your subscriber base?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start and Dave, if there's any additional color you want to add. We went through with the growth that we're seeing in e-commerce. Of course, it's a pretty small percentage of our sales, just under 6%. So -- And it was interesting was that as we
componenttext: Well, I'll start and Dave, if there's any additional color you want to add. We went through with the growth that we're seeing in e-commerce. Of course, it's a pretty small percentage of our sales, just under 6%. So -- And it was interesting was that as we look at that omnichannel shopper, or I guess multichannel shopper, we love that guest because they're our best guest in many ways. So the person who's shopping both in-store and online is driving 2.5x the sales that somebody who's only shopping on the store. So what that says to us is this is incremental. There's not quite a lot of replenishment-type activity happening. We talked about this. We focus on these beauty enthusiasts who's really focused on trend and newness. And actually, we get her email address, the ability to give her email, spark her imagination and curiosity about other products that maybe she didn't see in the store, seems to be driving. Whether it's that or beauty breaks or samples, they're really responding. So over time, we certainly see that expanding in terms of percentage of sales. It's a small percentage of our sales today in terms of multichannel shopper, but it's a very healthy place for us to continue to look at driving growth.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I'd add to that is what you see is this omnichannel guests, most of them pretty quickly as they come in through e-commerce, pretty quickly move into retail. And that's what we like to see. We want her experience in the entire ULTA Beau
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I'd add to that is what you see is this omnichannel guests, most of them pretty quickly as they come in through e-commerce, pretty quickly move into retail. And that's what we like to see. We want her experience in the entire ULTA Beauty experience, both online and in store. We're investing heavily in the areas, both enablers of omnichannel around our inventory and our understanding of our guests as well as guest experiences. We've talked in the past. We've got beacons in our stores now that allow us to -- will allow us over time to identify our guests. We've got same-day shipping with -- in partnership with Google, with -- Mary mentioned some of the app improvements, which will make it easier for her to buy anywhere at anytime she wants. So it's a big focus for us, and we see lots of upside going forward in that period.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the other one I just want to squeeze in. I know are you talked about Greenwood and Dallas in terms of the DCs. Just given that the last 3 years, you've made some key investments. obviously, you guys have been really doing a terrific job in terms
componenttext: And then the other one I just want to squeeze in. I know are you talked about Greenwood and Dallas in terms of the DCs. Just given that the last 3 years, you've made some key investments. obviously, you guys have been really doing a terrific job in terms of top line and bottom line. How does that make you think about the older DCs? Like as you're continued to really drive strong growth now, is now the time to maybe think about retrofitting some of the older DCs that eventually you might have to do just to obviously keep that best in class? So I was just wondering if that something that you guys internally talk about? Or you're happy at the way things over the older DCs, and down the road, maybe you just deal with it?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean it's part -- the whole supply network is part of that. We've got a road map built, right, 5 years into the future showing us different things that we're going to address at different points in time. So yes, you're right on, Jason. We're thinkin
componenttext: No. I mean it's part -- the whole supply network is part of that. We've got a road map built, right, 5 years into the future showing us different things that we're going to address at different points in time. So yes, you're right on, Jason. We're thinking about the rest of the network and those buildings. We'd like to have everyone on one platform, right, best-in-class kind of platform at one point in time. So those decisions are little bit out in front of us, but I would say definitely, that will be a focus of ours over the long term.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, just for you, I guess I'm sorry if I missed this. But on the gross margin, great, very impressive expansion this quarter. Can you just elaborate how much of that was merchandise core merchandise margin versus fixed costs leverage? And then of the 4
componenttext: Scott, just for you, I guess I'm sorry if I missed this. But on the gross margin, great, very impressive expansion this quarter. Can you just elaborate how much of that was merchandise core merchandise margin versus fixed costs leverage? And then of the 4% pricing in the quarter, maybe just how do we think about that in terms of product mix and then just higher like-for-like pricing, due to the pullback in couponing?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take a crack at that. So gross margin overall, we're not going to break out all the basis points, pluses and minuses here, puts and takes, but I can just directionally talk. And I know sometimes people, it may not be clear because this is kin
componenttext: Well, let me take a crack at that. So gross margin overall, we're not going to break out all the basis points, pluses and minuses here, puts and takes, but I can just directionally talk. And I know sometimes people, it may not be clear because this is kind of a multivariable equation that we're solving for when we talk about promotions, right? So there's a couple of major buckets, I guess I would call them. Merchants discounts, right, so what are the offers in the magazines that we distribute or the tabs that we put in the newspapers? Is it 2 for 1? Is it buy one, get one 50% off? Is there a GWP with it, right? So that's one bucket. And then there's the marketing discount bucket, right, which is the coupon, right, 3 50 off 10, 20% of one item, 20% off the entire order kind of thing, right, with the postcard offer that we described in the past. And then there's the loyalty, right? So that will be the third leg of the stool. So again we approach this very carefully, right, and we're testing and learning   . But if we look at the first quarter, for example, we talked about the mass area, right? So mass has been generating really healthy comps for us. We've kind of learned over the course of the last year that the merchandise discounts don't need to be as broad maybe as what it did in the past. This year, we kind of narrowed it down. Instead of 2 -- buy 2, get 1 across the whole brand, maybe it's just a narrower set of SKUs. So that would be one example of something that we executed very well in the first quarter. in there's just another set of other what I call smart merchandising marketing decisions, continuing to tweak our coupon offers and the circulation that we have on our marketing offers, ULTA Beauty Collection, private label, super high margin part of our business with especially strong in the first quarter this year. E-commerce, we called out again, product mix, being very helpful to us. So you got a lot of good things happening in the merch margin bucket, I would say. And then you layer on top of that a 15 comp right? That helps a lot on the fixed store cost line. We called that out in our comments. And then we have some offsets, some deleverage on supply chain, which was planned and which was expected. So that's kind of it. I guess I'd say in a nutshell. On the explanation of the variation year-over-year, when we think about the comp breakout and ticket bifurcation, units were pretty flat year-over-year, so most of it was on average selling price.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark with Robert W. Baird.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, thanks for all that detail in gross margin. I guess I wanted to follow up quickly on SG&A. Spending was up 25% in the quarter, which is presumably more than you initially planned when you built -- the plan for the quarter and for the year. So I gue
componenttext: Scott, thanks for all that detail in gross margin. I guess I wanted to follow up quickly on SG&A. Spending was up 25% in the quarter, which is presumably more than you initially planned when you built -- the plan for the quarter and for the year. So I guess can you break out just how much of that was pulled forward and some of the accelerated depreciation you referred to that would potentially allow greater leverage later in the year? And then to the extent you had more dollars to spend, given the top line growth, what are the areas where you've chosen to really intensify investment?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're really trying to stay focused on that and not break out too much detail kind of the variations. And I know you guys would love to have that. But again directionally, the store payroll, there's an investment there as we ramp up the boutiques.
componenttext: Yes, so we're really trying to stay focused on that and not break out too much detail kind of the variations. And I know you guys would love to have that. But again directionally, the store payroll, there's an investment there as we ramp up the boutiques. There was accelerated depreciation in the first quarter. It's going to be heavy again in the second quarter as we look -- compare against last year. I would say that there's some cost of doing business things that are in there. You guys read all these stores about credit card fraud and the whole EMV thing that all of retail is kind of struggling with. So we're not immune to that, right? We had some of that in the first quarter. Now lucky for us, our EMV rollout is complete now. So that, we've mitigated that risk as we look out -- across the rest of the year. I would also say that work, like we've done in the past, we look to optimize the business, right? So there's some additional investments, I guess I would call in the short term around some test-and-learn things around levers, future levers to drive growth, that we think we can move up here and accelerate little bit into 2016. And again, it was not [ph] on huge things, but there's a little bit here and a little bit there. So we're doing it in a very disciplined manner, making sure we have the right balance for both the short-term and long-term financial results of the business.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mary, you mentioned I think 3% of market share. I don't know if that was including or excluding services. But my question is, do you have a sense of the share of the beauty spend among your best customers? What percent of their wallet are you getting? And
componenttext: Mary, you mentioned I think 3% of market share. I don't know if that was including or excluding services. But my question is, do you have a sense of the share of the beauty spend among your best customers? What percent of their wallet are you getting? And then based on what you carry, I know this is a moving target because that will change over time. But based on what the carry, how much of that while it is attainable?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that 3% that I mentioned, if you take all of beauty products and services in the U.S. and that very macro view of it just kind of where we start. And then if you look at dollars that are spent in amongst the targets that we focused on, the beauty en
componenttext: Well, that 3% that I mentioned, if you take all of beauty products and services in the U.S. and that very macro view of it just kind of where we start. And then if you look at dollars that are spent in amongst the targets that we focused on, the beauty enthusiasts on a budget, certainly, it's higher. We have 5% of their share of wallet. Of the people that are in a loyalty program, well clearly, it's higher than that. But I'll tell you what, there's a lot of upside to that as well. if we look at our best guest, if you step back, there are, I don't know. I mean there are 50,000 places you can buy beauty in the U.S., right? So between grocery, mass, drug, department store, specialty retailer, online, there's lot of places you can buy beauty. So there's a lot of sources of   share gain that will ideal for us and our guests and to be really resonating is the more success with us loyalty program, right, the more benefit she gets by consolidating per spend at ULTA. So we had not had that you do in terms of the number of relevant, the addressable market [indiscernible] folks that are could be in our loyalty program as well as -- We'll never have 100% of anybody's wallet, I think. That's kind of in any category, think about grocery for example. People buy food probably in 2 or 3 or 4 different types of retail outlets. It's probably always going to be a little bit of like that and beauty. But we feel good about where it is and there's a lot of potential for that growth.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. In terms of the drivers, honestly, it really is a combination of a lot of factors. They really, I guess you can point most directly to the acceleration the growth of the member. So a 25% increase in the members and ULTAmate Rewards program
componenttext: Thank you, Dan. In terms of the drivers, honestly, it really is a combination of a lot of factors. They really, I guess you can point most directly to the acceleration the growth of the member. So a 25% increase in the members and ULTAmate Rewards program, that clearly, we can point to as a major driver. So more guests in the program and guests spending more often, reactivation of guests, better retention. Now that doesn't happen kind of by accident, right? So it's really a combination of, I would say, everything we're doing. I mentioned at the top, I mean, it's good to be in a category that's going and beauty, we believe, what we have is a very compelling proposition relative to a large segment of the market, right? So what we offer them is relevant and as we look out into the future, the future consumer and the line is, I think even more so relevant. But even within addition, right, we had to be driving awareness and traffic. So I feel great about what I recall our demand creation tool. So we wouldn't have an increase in the number. If it didn't have new people aware of the coming to trend in the traffic shows that. And then in addition, of course, it's about what we saw in the store and a service that we give and the services and a guest experience. So I talked a lot about the merchandise assortment. So I feel good about we're really doing business smartly with our brand partners. So I guess in total, it's a lot of things coming together I think effectively for us to drive members and to a loyalty program and have a relevant proposition to drive the growth. The second part you asked about was, yes there is a lot obviously happening as it relates to wages and whatnot. In particular, overtime pay thing that just passed. We are -- we've already factored that into our forecast. There is some   impact [ph] to us this year. it's immaterial, I would say. Those managers are typically paid above the threshold, and some of our comanagers are affected. [ph] And as you look out into future years, we'll continue to obviously be cognizant of that in factoring each and other pay factors.

componenttext: No. I guess we won't share any of that detail, but -- yes. Yes. We did grow our total awareness, and we've shared that in the past. componenttext: Yes, I think we've share this last time. So we started the year with -- we talked about in the couple of hundred range of Clinique and Lancôme this year. Yes, 500, in the approximately 500 new boutiques across Lancôme and Benefit, those 3 brands. We will see growth over the year. We're just getting those new ones open. So while it had some impact on Q1, was not the big driver of Q1. And frankly, I don't -- it will be a contributor, but there's a lot of other parts of our business to driving growth, a lot of other brands in prestige space like mass, hair care, skin care. it will continue to drive growth, but we're not counting on that being the primary driver of growth throughout the rest of the year.

And we'll -- as we mentioned, as our brand gross, as our recognition grows and then we improve its presentation and quality of product's overall merchandising strategy, March and strategy, we'll see that grow as well.

componenttext: Let me just say, I think part of this, we'll talk about in the fall as we do the Analyst Day. That is, we think about the way the world   [indiscernible] the world today sort of the influences are really converging nicely as it relates to beauty as a category as well is shopping in the way that we offer, to be able to come in with a point of view and be -- already have curated idea in mind that to get as well. And if you can add a little bit more to that, but more on this topic later, I say is the best way to think about it.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes, the only thing I'd say is our growth, we're excited to see in our growth. As I mentioned earlier, it isn't concentrated on a specific age range or geographic profile. It's really just beauty enthusiasts, and she's all ages. she lives all across the country. we're seeing strength with teenagers. There's been reports that come from other third parties about ULTA continuing to gain strength and presence with teenagers, certainly millennials, but through all the way through races. And of course, a great part of beauty is, it's not that age dependent. Needs might change, but the desire to be part of the beauty category continues. so we're seeing that across the board right now.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

componenttext: Second follow up, sounds like the boutiques, while they're rolling in, are only about or starting to really impact the business. As you think about historical experience and the kind of pops [indiscernible] to the business relative to the double-digit same-store sales you've been posting, without that catalyst, is the input or the additional volume from this boutiques material in that context? Or is this something that you just sort of absorbed by the strong growth that you've got these days?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes I think in the short term, it's absorbed. So again, back to Dave's earlier point, it's going to be additive. It takes a while for these boutiques to ramp up similar to our store. Maturation curve overall, we've seen that demonstrated over a long perio
componenttext: Yes I think in the short term, it's absorbed. So again, back to Dave's earlier point, it's going to be additive. It takes a while for these boutiques to ramp up similar to our store. Maturation curve overall, we've seen that demonstrated over a long period of time. So again over the longer term, yes. We think it's a significant add to the box overall and will help productivity significantly over the long term.

componenttext: Okay, so we'll tag team this again, Dave? I'll start on the mall piece. Malls are about 10% or so of our store base, and we're not really -- we're not seeing much difference. We're seeing positive traffic. I would say when we're in malls, we pick   spots pretty carefully, both in terms of the market, it being at a great place to sharp in a given market, as well as our locations tend to be on exterior of them all. So we feel good about how they're performing.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes and our new brands, not -- nothing to report specifically here. But I will say as has been our trends of late, we'll continue to add new brands. But I say, that is a big contributor. We're also, I mentioned this earlier, we're really focused on drivin
componenttext: Yes and our new brands, not -- nothing to report specifically here. But I will say as has been our trends of late, we'll continue to add new brands. But I say, that is a big contributor. We're also, I mentioned this earlier, we're really focused on driving growth with our existing brands. Have a lot of new products coming in and growth with existing products within our portfolio across many of the brands that Mary mentioned in her remarks. So it will be a mix, continue to drive with our big brands like Urban Decay and Redken and Too Faced but then, we'll certainly complement that with new brands throughout the year.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have one question on the brand boutiques. wonder if you can give us a little bit more information on the return on invested capital, or some of the productivity goals that you have within that floor space? And given the $80 million investment I thi
componenttext: I just have one question on the brand boutiques. wonder if you can give us a little bit more information on the return on invested capital, or some of the productivity goals that you have within that floor space? And given the $80 million investment I think that you talked about so far. Can you talk to us about the brands are committed to, whether it's capital or exclusive products or marketing?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes let me start there. So as far as the $80 million is concerned, I mean, that's all ULTA, right? So we're stepping up for that CapEx investment. And again, that $80 million, it's not just the boutique drop-in, right? So again, there's 500, roughly 500 i
componenttext: Yes let me start there. So as far as the $80 million is concerned, I mean, that's all ULTA, right? So we're stepping up for that CapEx investment. And again, that $80 million, it's not just the boutique drop-in, right? So again, there's 500, roughly 500 individual boutiques drop-ins across the chain. But we're going to take the opportunity when enter the stores to also refresh our fragrance fixtures in those stores and ULTA Beauty Collection fixture in it as well, as well as other miscellaneous things, right? Enter the store, touching it up, and cost some cash. You're going to take the opportunity to do what you think is best for the guest long term. So that's how we're deploying the $80 million. Again, each vendor, we have a different set of economic terms with them. So I think by and large it's kind of, it's a payroll share kind of model, right? So again, they're trained. They are associates. They are on the payroll. The vendors provide, our vendor partners provide excellent training for them. We kind of share the payroll model on a go-forward basis. And it takes a while -- again, we install the boutiques up front. It takes a while for this to reach maturity, right? So again as we go over time, we had more payroll resources there to make the more productive. So I think that's it in a nutshell.

componenttext: What we've shared I think a couple of quarters ago that we've seen an increase in I guess what we call reactivation, which lapsed customers. And so we've seen a healthy increase with that. Probably won't get into sharing that every quarter, but that is part of it. So customers that shopped with us 2 years ago would that be considered a current customer. But we have a record of them. They come back in. They reactivate the account. And they would move into our active group, move back into our active member profile. So that's a chunk of it. But the biggest part of it is new-to-ULTA customers. And that is exactly as you described, customers coming in and shopping at ULTA and starting that experience as a new customer. And then when they get up and interact with one of our associates, become one of our customer during the visit there. And a key part of our success has been our sort of associates really doing an excellent job converting nonmembers and to members in the store and we've seen a strong increase in that. So that's, that is the primary driver of our new member growth.

All in when we think that 100, it's kind of a good pace.

componenttext: Yes, No problem, Omar. I guess what I would say is yes, we have several urban, I guess call them, stores in the fleet. And they do fine. I talked about that we feel good about 10,000 square foot store format and the ability to hit at least 1,200 [indiscernible] that format. But I referenced at, we're also looking at what's opportunity in smaller markets and then also what's the opportunity is in place where the parcels of real estate will by definition be smaller. So whether it's urban centers or the downtown maybe shopping area of high-end suburbs, right? So all I -- we've got 2 [indiscernible] with two 5,000 square foot stores we're operating to learn more about the dynamics of the different types of. And they're doing well. We're also learning about the best way to operate that. And as we look at refreshing view of store growth, urban is a question for asking ourselves we look at. And the economics are different. As we drive brand awareness across the country with our marketing efforts, we know that we've -- whenever we go now, people know more about us than they would have in the past. So that's a good way to placed some more to come on that.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us for Ulta Beauty's first quarter 2016 conference call. Hosting our call are Mary Dillon, Chief Executive Officer; and Scott Settersten, Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us as Dave Kimbell, Chief Merc
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us for Ulta Beauty's first quarter 2016 conference call. Hosting our call are Mary Dillon, Chief Executive Officer; and Scott Settersten, Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us as Dave Kimbell, Chief Merchandising and Marketing Officer. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you the company's safe harbor language. Statements contained in this conference call which are not historical fact may be deemed to constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual future results may differ materially from those projected in such statements due to a number of risks and uncertainties, all of which are described in the company's filings with the SEC. 
[Operator Instructions] I'll now turn it over to Mary.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura. Good afternoon, everyone. 2016 is off to great start with excellent top and bottom line growth in our first quarter. There are several factors coming together to drive momentum in our business: healthy consumer demand in the beauty categ
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura. Good afternoon, everyone. 2016 is off to great start with excellent top and bottom line growth in our first quarter. There are several factors coming together to drive momentum in our business: healthy consumer demand in the beauty category, ULTA Beauty's unique and relevant format and positioning and effective collaboration across the enterprise, which is driving strong execution of our growth strategy. 
To recap the first quarter results: we drew -- grew the top line 23.7% and delivered a 15.2% comp on top of an 11.4% comp in the first quarter 2015. This is our best comp growth since 2006. Comp sales were driven primarily by traffic, while ticket also saw healthy increases. Ongoing strength in cosmetics, both mass and prestige, is largest contributor to our growth, but other major categories for delivering robust comps as well. E-commerce continues to see rapid sales growth. The Salon's top line was selling, even while we reduced the frequency of our promotion period. So with the overall revenue growth significantly better than planned, coupled with strong execution of our strategic imperatives, we delivered earnings per share growth of almost 40%, well above our expectations. 
I'd like to call out some more specific details on the primary contributors for our performance during the quarter. Growth in our loyalty program continues to fuel business results. ULTAmate Rewards membership grew to 19.4 million active members, up 25% year-over-year. This continued acceleration of sign-ups reflect store associates' efforts to convert new members and strong traffic driven apart by our advertising campaign. 
The number of members shopping increased as well as their sales ticket per visit. loyalty member retention increased each quarter and is up almost 200 basis points compared to last year. Using the loyalty program points as currency, our CRM team is working closely with our merchants and our brand partners to continue developing targeted and relevant campaigns that are increasingly resonating with our guests. 
Our marketing mix continues to evolve with great balance across television, radio, digital and social media as well as our traditional print vehicle. In March, we ran television and radio ads for our signature 21 Days of Beauty event. complemented this with an aggressive online video campaign as well as extensions into online radio with Spotify and Pandora. 
We elevated our social media and influence efforts anchored on our spring trends. We surrounded our consumer with current and relevant content online and in-store as well as activation at high-profile events, including the Coachella music Festival. Our comprehensive campaign for Mother's Day, which was called pamper Her with  , was designed to build awareness that our brand, deepen our connection with our guests and provide a platform to make ULTA Beauty a top-of-mind destination for gift-giving, especially in fragrance. In addition to the return of the Mother's Day gift guide and fragrance finder, we offered more gifts purchase and CRM promotions in conjunction with many exciting new fragrance launches. The Mother's Day activities also included a social media campaign with the launch of a special video entitled Mom, the Original Beauty Icon, which invited guests to celebrate mom by sharing what makes their own moms' beauty iconic through a post on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. This campaign was viewed over 4.5 million times. We believe all these marketing efforts contributed to our strong traffic growth during the quarter. 
Now to update you on merchandising. The trends from last year continued to drive business, with Urban Decay, cosmetics, Mix, , Too Faced,, Clinique, Lancôme, Benefit and Ulta Beauty Collection along the best performing brands in the quarter. The pipeline of newness really continues to be quite compelling, translating into strong growth in both mass and prestige cosmetics. During the quarter, we launched Honest [ph] Beauty in 250 stores, rolled out our exclusive Feeling the [indiscernible] in 500 stores and added Cosmetics to all doors. Anastacia, Beverly Hills and launched new product lines. Clarence was rolled out to additional doors. We entered [indiscernible] Double Duty beauty Collection, which is exclusive to ULTA Beauty. And we rolled that Dior mascara to all stores. 
More recently, we announced the addition of [indiscernible] hair care products, and we began to offer a French skincare brand on our website. We also rolled out an assortment of the iconic drive bar hair products and tools in hundreds of stores. 
We are enhancing our ULTA Beauty Collection through a series of initiatives. we've been updating and elevating the formula and packaging as well as the in-store graphics, while improving speed to market and on trend products. Trend categories include contouring, strobing and multidimensional makeup. And we've also added an featuring new spring kids. We've produced compelling training videos and enhanced our sampling program. while we've made great progress, we're just getting started with our efforts to involve ULTA Beauty Collection to continue to represent our brand personality. 
Turning to services. Our salon sales rose 14.7% and comped 7.7%, with strength in blowouts, hair treatment and makeup services. We view the services business as a growth opportunity, and we're very focused on our strategy to convert more of our loyalty members to discover a high-quality services offering. Our Benefit Brow Bar business continued its strong performance, with brow services now in 738 stores. And we're proud to perform more brow service than anyone else in the U.S. 
Moving on to stores. We opened 13 stores and closed one in the first quarter, well on our way to executing our 2016 program of 100 net new stores. We ended the quarter with 886 stores. New store productivity remains very strong, with all vintages of stores benefiting from the successful execution of our strategic imperatives. Our growth and development team is now in the process of performing a deep dive analysis to refresh our estimate of the store potential in the U.S. This analysis includes an updated assessment of the potential for smaller and urban market as well as how our small store format will fit into the future storm mix.  Sharing the outcome of this work is expected to be one of the topics we plan to cover at our next Analyst Day this fall as well as other updates from our long-term strategic plan that we're now in the process of refreshing as well. 
Moving on to www.ulta.com. Our e-commerce growth was very strong, up 38.8% and contributing 130 basis points of total company comp. The mix of professional health care and prestige cosmetics continues to grow, helping our e-commerce margin rate. We are also adding brands and products that are available online such as Beauty,   hair care,   [indiscernible] among others. Our ulta.com guests remain very interested in our beauty bag sampling program and beauty break limited time promotions. 
Mobile is growing rapidly, now representing more than 60% of site traffic. We released new versions of our iPhone and Android apps in the first quarter. The iPhone app was featured on Apple Store home page. Moving up to a 5-star rating, this new version now includes features such as Apple Pay checkout, enhanced features displaying ULTAmate Rewards information and Gifts with Purchase details on product pages. Both app versions have been a big hit with users, garnering enthusiastic user reviews and an increase in downloads, now reaching well over 2 million between the two. 
Finally, our supply chain and IT teams have done a great job managing the ramp-up of the Greenwood distribution center while preparing to open our distribution center in Dallas, which began inbound inventories last week. The Greenwood DC is now serving about 200 stores and fulfilling roughly 40% of our e-commerce orders. We're on track to end the year delivering to approximately 240 stores from Greenwood. 
Our Dallas facility, a carbon copy of our Greenwood building, is right on track to begin outbound shipments in July as planned. We expect to ramp up this newest DC to serve 125 stores by holiday. As expected, the Greenwood distribution center and systems are producing efficiencies and cost per unit shipped. 
On the system side, we have good progress to report here as well. Swift, our forecasting replenishment tool, has been rolled out to additional categories including skincare and health care, and rest of categories will be implemented throughout the remainder of the year. I am particularly proud of the supply chain team and IT teams' performance in the collaboration and balancing execution of several major initiatives and projects while of doing an excellent job improving in stocks in our stores to support the higher-than-expected sales trends. 
So now I'll turn it over to Scott to discuss the drivers of our first quarter results and outlook for the second quarter and the year.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mary. Good afternoon, everyone. Starting with the income statement. Similar to previous quarters, our top line was driven by a very healthy 15.2% comp and strong new store productivity. The total company comp was composed of 11% transaction grow
componenttext:
Thanks, Mary. Good afternoon, everyone. 
Starting with the income statement. Similar to previous quarters, our top line was driven by a very healthy 15.2% comp and strong new store productivity. The total company comp was composed of 11% transaction growth and 4.2% average ticket growth. The retail comp of 14.3% was made up 10.5% traffic and 3.8% ticket. The Salon business comped 7.7%, and salon growth was all ticket based. e-commerce growth was almost entirely driven by traffic, with modest ticket growth. 
Gross profit increased 150 basis points. The improvement was driven by strong leverage on store rent and occupancy expenses as well as product margin expansion, offset by planned supply chain deleverage related to investments in new distribution centers and core merchandising systems. Strong product margin performance was driven in part by significant margin improvement in mass departments due to changes in our promotional offers and a mix of higher margin brands, including the ULTA Beauty Collection. We continued to carefully pull back on broad discounting, while placing more reliance on loyalty and our CRM tool kit. 
Moving on to SG&A expenses. We deleveraged by 20 basis points, primarily related to investments and headcount and consulting to support our growth initiatives. 
Turning to the balance sheet and cash flow. Inventories were up 14.5% on a per-store basis, slightly below the comp rate. This growth was driven by investments in inventory to keep up with better-than-expected top line growth, new brand additions and the accelerated expansion of prestige boutiques. In-stock levels have improved year-over-year, but we still expect to make more progress going forward as we begin to reap the benefits of our new distribution centers and related systems. 
Capital expenditures were $54.3 million in the quarter driven by new store openings, merchandise features for the rollout of prestige brand boutiques and supply chain and system investments. 
We ended the quarter with $369 million in cash and short-term investments. 
We repurchased 158,000 shares at a cost of $27 million under our 10b5-1 plan. And as you know, we entered into a $200 million ASR agreement in March, which settled just last week. During the first quarter, we received 80% of the shares we expected to receive on settlement, or about 852,000 shares. The reduction in shares outstanding year-over-year contributed approximately $0.03 of earnings per share growth in the quarter. Including the entire $200 million paid as part of the ASR agreement, approximately $219 million remained available under the $425 million share repurchase program announced in March. 
Turning now to guidance for the second quarter. We anticipate sales to be in the range of $1.041 billion to $1.058 billion compared to $877 million last year. We expect comparable sales to increase in the range of 11% to 13% versus 10.1% last year. Online sales growth is expected to be in the 40% range. We plan to open about 25 stores in Q2 compared to 20 stores during the same period last year. And preopening expense for the quarter is expected to be about $4.6 million. 
Earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $1.32 to $1.37 versus $1.15 for Q2 of 2015.  Our supply chain investments, including new Dallas DC, are expected to weigh on margins the most in the second and third quarter. And we expect earnings per share growth to be higher in the fourth quarter this year.  We anticipate a tax rate of 37.6% and a fully diluted share count of approximately 63 million. 
In terms of our outlook for the full year 2016, we are raising our guidance for comparable sales and earnings per share growth to reflect the strong start to the year. Total company comps are now expected to be approximately 10% to 12% compared to our prior guidance of 8% to 10%. We now expect to grow earnings per share in the low 20s percentage range versus our prior guidance of 18% to 20% growth. Operating margins are now expected to leverage slightly. 
The other elements of our guidance for the year are unchanged. We are on track to open approximately 100 stores, all planned to be on 10,000 square foot prototype. We expect to open about 25 stores in Q2, 50 stores in Q3 and 15 stores in Q4. 
We're also planning 12 major remodels and 2 relocations. We plan to grow e-commerce approximately 40%. We expect CapEx to be about $390 million, driven by higher capital per new store and the rollout of boutiques. As a reminder, we planned about $80 million for boutique expansion and updates, with over 500 Clinique, Lancôme and Benefit boutiques as well as updates to our fragrance fixtures and the ULTA Beauty Collection. 
We anticipate that share repurchase activity under our $425 million authorization will contribute about 2 percentage points of earnings per share growth. 
I'll now turn the call over to our conference call host for the Q&A session. Operator?

Where we did see variation, it was maybe cadence of promotion than we had planned. So I think at the end of the day, beauty as a category is a great place to be as you know. And its healthy's category and it's fairly, we think, insulated from some of the factors that are affecting may be retail broadly. And in particular, our -- what we bring to the marketplace in terms of this differentiator proposition categories, various price points our products and services, we think makes is pretty insulated right now. And we're pretty proud of the results.

componenttext: Yes, I can. Our store model reflects mature stores 5 years and older kind of moderate and comp kind of middle, low single-digit kind of comps over the long term. With the 15 comp in total, as you can well imagine, Chris, I mean the existing store base, very healthy comps overall, very productive on the   contribution line, which is a huge contributor to the profit increases that we saw year-over-year. As we look to the future, I mean, that's part of the mix. We're adding the boutiques. That's why we're being so aggressive with the CapEx this year and get those installed. We believe that as well as with all the other great purchase of pipeline that we have coming onboard, loyalty on top of that, some of the marketing and advertising kind of initiatives we have underway, we think all of those things together will come together to drive really strong productivity in our existing store base.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Well first of all, I would say we've said it's well over 80%, over 80% of our sales are driven by the loyalty program members. We're really pleased with how that's working for our business. The -- it's really one of the key drivers of the
componenttext: Thank you, Joe. Well first of all, I would say we've said it's well over 80%, over 80% of our sales are driven by the loyalty program members. We're really pleased with how that's working for our business. The -- it's really one of the key drivers of the results that we're seeing is the acceleration in members entering the program. proud about our store teams being able to convert new traffic and new members into the store and into the program. How high is that? I mean, certainly, we have to resolve that question as well. As we think about kind of long-term view of the business, it's going to be obviously a very key driver for us as we move forward. And if you step way back and look at it, our share of the market in beauty in the U.S. is still only 3% or so of the total market, right? So we know there's a lot of growth ahead. And we're very focused on understanding kind of what it is about loyalty program that drives the appeal in continue to make sure that we fine-tune it going forward. So we think there's more growth there certainly, and I think our results are showing that.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood, and then just moving on I guess one for Scott. The guide for Q2, you mentioned was like a earnings per share down sequentially. That's seasonally unusual. You mentioned some of the costs related to Dallas hitting you in 2Q and 3Q. You ha
componenttext: Okay, understood, and then just moving on I guess one for Scott. The guide for Q2, you mentioned was like a earnings per share down sequentially. That's seasonally unusual. You mentioned some of the costs related to Dallas hitting you in 2Q and 3Q. You had Greenwood facility around the same time last year, and yet, you had sequential earnings improvement in 2Q. So I'm just curious, is Dallas bigger in terms of the impact? Or is the timing a little bit moved forward relative to Greenwood?

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would say it's probably more along the lines of a couple of new factors this year. So I guess we kind of talked about the DCs and the lapping effect there year-over-year. So not a huge change there, I would say, in the sequence. We do have accelerat
componenttext: No, I would say it's probably more along the lines of a couple of new factors this year. So I guess we kind of talked about the DCs and the lapping effect there year-over-year. So not a huge change there, I would say, in the sequence. We do have accelerated depreciation from this boutique acceleration that we talked about, so again, you guys can't model that very accurately. But that's a little bit lumpy, and it's kind of first half of the year kind of weighted, I would say. And then we also have some store payroll implications related to the same boutique strategy, right? So I think we explained back in the fourth quarter that it takes a lot for those boutiques to ramp up, right? So they're being installed now and we got some payroll investment there in the early days, which over time, moderates and plays very well part from a profitability standpoint. So it's really the payroll piece, and some of it's the depreciation that's related there, That's causing it.

headline: ULTA Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 26, 2016
